bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, August 13, 1941

div1.p: Hench discusses changes to Cornwell's "Conquerors of Yellow Fever" painting that would improve its historical accuracy.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, August 13, 1941
div1.opener:
leave on desk.
August 13, 1941
Mr. George A. Kellogg
257 Cornelison Avenue
Jersey City, N. J.
My dear Mr. Kellogg:
div1.p:
I never did quite understand how it came to pass that Cornwell included
as many figures as he did in the yellow fever painting. You recall my original
suggestion was to confine the figures to the five hot-shots--the four Americans
and Finlay. Then Truby suggested many figures, more or less all those connected
in any way with the experiments and mentioned various names. The upshot of it
was a compromise whereby Cornwell included fourteen figures, of which only seven
were really identified. I gather from you that you were willing to let the
other men stand for anyone who wanted to think he or his relative was in the
painting, but I think that is a bad thing from the standpoint of history. You may
be pleasing some people who are momentarily alive but history will demand a better
accounting than that. At my suggestion, Cornwell did include the fifteenth figure--
the Cuban volunteer placed between Moran and Kissinger. Undoubtedly with the en-
couragement of others but on my suggestion also, it was decided to consider the
seated figure on the left General Kean, the seated figure in the center, General
Wood, the standing figure between Finlay and Agramonte was to become General Truby
and Dr. Cook was to be one of the two figures on the porch railing. From the very
start I understood that the mustached figure on Moran's right was to be Jernegan.
That still leaves two figures “anonymous” as the newspaper article expressed it.
I shall be glad indeed to go into a huddle with myself and with Generals Kean
and Truby, and at my very earliest convenience will nominate names for these two
or three other men. I suspect that the figure whose face is not very clear and
who is placed in the background behind Moran was more or less planned to be Andrus.
Since he was one of the very last who volunteered, the only claim that he has to get
in the painting is that he, according to his own story, took Reed's place as volun-
teer and secondly, he has been personally helpful to you all. I do think that the
painting must be purposeful in every detail and that each person should be identi-
fied. In the description of the painting there is plenty of space for you to state
definitely that these men were chosen to represent their colleagues whose names
were actually mentioned in my paper.

I have not yet received the early proof but will be anxious indeed to see
it. Your preliminary plans for the McDowell painting sound most interesting. I
have had a great deal of fun out of the yellow fever painting and wish indeed that
I were enough of an authority to help you with the next one.

Incidentally, I came across a catalog from a concern that sells autographed
letters. They have two or three letters of Dorothy Dix. Would you like to have them?

I was very much interested in the New York Sunday Mirror article and sent
them a check last week to send me twenty-five copies. The check has been returned
with the statement that they have no copies available. I don't want to rob you of
Mr. George A. Kellogg
- 2 -
August 13, 1941
your own copies but if I could buy a dozen without disturbing you, I should be
very happy to do so. I enclose a carbon copy of a letter that I am sending to
Fred Rankin. I happened to play the organ at Fred's marriage to Edith Mayo.
I have known Freddy for years although I was always more friendly to Edith than
to Fred.

I will be attending the Wisconsin State Medical Meeting as I am chairman
of a luncheon round table discussion and I am also invited to read a paper before
the general session and so I will be glad to see the painting at that time. Will
you be along with the painting?

Can you send me a couple more photographs of the painting or a couple of
extra colored reproductions of the painting upon the margins of which I can make
notes to send to Truby and Kean?
div1.closer: Very sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
